infodynamics.measures.continuous

Interface MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate

  • All Superinterfaces:
    ChannelCalculatorCommon, ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKernel, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov1, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov2, MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon

    public interface MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
extends ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate

    Interface for implementations of the mutual information, which may be applied to either multivariate or merely univariate continuous data. That is, it is applied to double[][] data, where the first index is observation number or time, and the second is variable number.

    Usage of the child classes implementing this interface is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator;
    2. Set properties using ChannelCalculatorCommon.setProperty(String, String) which may now include the property PROP_TIME_DIFF to specify a source-destination time difference (default 0);
    3. Initialise the calculator using ChannelCalculatorCommon.initialise() or ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.initialise(int, int);
    4. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using:
      • ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.setObservations(double[][], double[][]), ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.setObservations(double[][], double[][], boolean[], boolean[]) or ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.setObservations(double[][], double[][], boolean[][], boolean[][]) for calculations based on single time-series, OR
      • The following sequence:
        1. ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(), then
        2. One or more calls to ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.addObservations(double[][], double[][]) or ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate.addObservations(double[][], double[][], int, int), then
        3. ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations();
    5. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average MI: ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • the local MI values for these samples: ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
      • local MI values for a specific set of samples: #computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[])
      • the distribution of MI values under the null hypothesis of no relationship between source and destination values: ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeSignificance(int) or ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeSignificance(int[][]).
    6. Return to step 2 or 3 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)
    See Also:
    "T. M. Cover and J. A. Thomas, 'Elements of Information Theory' (John Wiley & Sons, New York, 1991)."

    • Method Detail

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        double computeAverageLocalOfObservations(int[] newOrdering)
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the mutual information if the observations of the first variable (source) were ordered as per the ordering specified in newOrdering.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of a shuffled source series here.

        This method is primarily intended for use in ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeSignificance(int[][]) however has been made public in case users wish to access it.

        Parameters:
        newOrdering - a specification of how to shuffle the source values to create a surrogate source time series. It is an array of length N (where would be the value returned by ChannelCalculatorCommon.getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the surrogate MI score if the source values were shuffled as specified.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
